company.name: Verkada Inc.
company.business_description: Verkada is a cloud-based building security company that sells security cameras and other physical security products to over 12,000 businesses throughout the U.S. and abroad. The company's customers span multiple industries, including education, government, healthcare, and hospitality. Approximately 80% of Verkada's security camera and building access control customers are businesses with 500 or fewer employees.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 7(a) of the Controlling the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography and Marketing Act of 2003 (CAN-SPAM Act), 15 U.S.C. § 7706(a)

complaint.factual_background: Verkada Inc., a cloud-based building security company, sold security cameras to over 12,000 businesses—including schools and healthcare facilities—while failing to implement reasonable information security practices. These failures allowed a threat actor in March 2021 to gain Super Admin access to Verkada's network, view over 150,000 live customer cameras, and exfiltrate gigabytes of sensitive customer and consumer data. Despite these failures, Verkada falsely claimed to be HIPAA certified or compliant and Privacy Shield certified, and falsely represented that its products used industry-standard and best-in-class data security safeguards. Verkada also orchestrated undisclosed positive reviews by its own employees and a venture capital investor on Google Maps, and repeatedly violated the CAN-SPAM Act by sending millions of commercial emails without opt-out mechanisms, failing to honor opt-out requests, and omitting valid physical postal addresses.

counts.title: Unfair Information Security Practices (Business Customers)
counts.representation: Verkada failed to take reasonable steps to prevent unauthorized access to customers' personal information on its network and customer cameras
counts.fact: Defendant's acts or practices caused or are likely to cause substantial injury to customers that customers cannot reasonably avoid themselves and that is not outweighed by countervailing benefits
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant's acts or practices as described in Paragraph 82 constitute unfair acts or practices in violation of Section 5 of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n).

counts.title: Unfair Information Security Practices (Consumers)
counts.representation: Verkada failed to take reasonable steps to prevent unauthorized access to consumers' personal information, including video footage of consumers at sensitive locations
counts.fact: Defendant's acts or practices caused or are likely to cause substantial injury to consumers that consumers cannot reasonably avoid themselves and that is not outweighed by countervailing benefits
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant's acts or practices as described in Paragraph 85 constitute unfair acts or practices in violation of Section 5 of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n).

counts.title: Information Security Misrepresentations
counts.representation: Verkada represented that it uses appropriate safeguards to protect customers' and consumers' personal information collected through its security cameras
counts.fact: Verkada did not use appropriate safeguards to protect customers' and consumers' personal information collected through its security cameras
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant's representations as described in Paragraph 88 are false or misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Information Security Misrepresentations — Command Platform
counts.representation: Verkada represented that it uses appropriate safeguards to protect customers' and consumers' personal information on the Command platform
counts.fact: Verkada did not use appropriate safeguards to protect customers' and consumers' personal information on the Command platform
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant's representations as described in Paragraph 91 are false or misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: HIPAA Misrepresentations
counts.representation: Verkada represented that its security camera systems are HIPAA certified or compliant
counts.fact: Verkada's security camera systems are not HIPAA certified or compliant; a third-party security posture assessment found no evidence of compliance and no fully implemented HIPAA framework
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant's representations as described in Paragraph 94 are false or misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Privacy Shield Compliance Misrepresentations
counts.representation: Verkada represented that it adhered to the EU-U.S. and Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield principles, including the principle of security
counts.fact: Verkada did not adhere to the EU-U.S. and Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield principles, including the principle of security, because it failed to take reasonable and appropriate security measures to protect consumers' personal information
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant's representations as set forth in Paragraph 97 are false or misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: False Claim of Impartial Ratings and Reviews
counts.representation: Verkada represented that online consumer ratings and reviews of Verkada or its products reflect the experiences or opinions of ordinary, impartial customers
counts.fact: The online consumer ratings and reviews were not from ordinary impartial customers, but were instead written by Verkada employees or a venture capital investor without disclosure of their association
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant's representations described in Paragraph 100 are false or misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Deceptive Failure to Disclose Material Connections
counts.representation: Verkada represented that online consumer ratings and reviews on Google Maps reflect its customers' opinions or experiences
counts.fact: The ratings and reviews were written by Verkada employees or a venture capital investor; this material connection was never disclosed to consumers, and such information would be material to consumers in evaluating reviews for a purchase decision
counts.conclusion: Defendant's failure to disclose the material information as described in Paragraph 104 constitutes a deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Failure to Honor Opt-Out Requests (CAN-SPAM)
counts.representation: Verkada initiated transmission of commercial email messages to recipients more than ten business days after receipt of a request not to receive further commercial emails
counts.fact: Recipients who requested to opt out continued to receive Verkada promotional emails beyond the ten-business-day window required by law
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant's acts or practices as described in Paragraph 115 violate Section 5(a)(4)(A) of the CAN-SPAM Act, 15 U.S.C. § 7704(a)(4)(A), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Failure to Provide Notice of Opt-Out (CAN-SPAM)
counts.representation: Verkada initiated transmission of commercial electronic mail messages that did not provide a clear and conspicuous notice of the opportunity to decline further commercial emails
counts.fact: Verkada's commercial emails did not include clear and conspicuous opt-out notice as required by the CAN-SPAM Act
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant's acts or practices as described in Paragraph 117 violate Section 5(a)(5)(A)(ii) of the CAN-SPAM Act, 15 U.S.C. § 7704(a)(5)(A)(ii), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: Failure to Provide Valid Physical Postal Address (CAN-SPAM)
counts.representation: Verkada initiated transmission of commercial electronic mail messages that did not provide a valid physical postal address
counts.fact: Verkada's commercial emails did not consistently include a valid physical postal address as required by the CAN-SPAM Act
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant's acts or practices, as described in Paragraph 119 violate Section 5(a)(5)(A)(iii) of the CAN-SPAM Act, 15 U.S.C. § 7704(a)(5)(A)(iii), and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

definitions.Clear(ly) and Conspicuous(ly): means that a required disclosure is difficult to miss (i.e., easily noticeable) and easily understandable by ordinary consumers, including in all of the following ways: 1. In any communication that is solely visual or solely audible, the disclosure must be made through the same means through which the communication is presented. In any communication made through both visual and audible means, such as a television advertisement, the disclosure must be presented simultaneously in both the visual and audible portions of the communication even if the representation requiring the disclosure is made in only one means. 2. A visual disclosure, by its size, contrast, location, the length of time it appears, and other characteristics, must stand out from any accompanying text or other visual elements so that it is easily noticed, read, and understood. 3. An audible disclosure, including by telephone or streaming video, must be delivered in a volume, speed, and cadence sufficient for ordinary consumers to easily hear and understand it. 4. In any communication using an interactive electronic medium, such as the Internet or software, the disclosure must be unavoidable. 5. The disclosure must use diction and syntax understandable to ordinary consumers and must appear in each language in which the representation that requires the disclosure appears. 6. The disclosure must comply with these requirements in each medium through which it is received, including all electronic devices and face-to-face communications. 7. The disclosure must not be contradicted or mitigated by, or inconsistent with, anything else in the communication. 8. When the representation or sales practice targets a specific audience, such as children, the elderly, or the terminally ill, "ordinary consumers" includes reasonable members of that group.
definitions.Commercial Electronic Mail Message: means any Electronic Mail Message the primary purpose of which is the commercial advertisement or promotion of a commercial product or service (including content on an Internet website operated for a commercial purpose).
definitions.Covered Incident: means any incident that results in Defendant notifying, pursuant to a statutory or regulatory requirement, any U.S. federal, state, or local government entity that information of or about an individual consumer was, or is reasonably believed to have been, accessed, acquired, or publicly exposed without authorization.
definitions.Covered Product: means (a) any security camera, building access control device, or other physical device designed, marketed, and offered by Defendant; and (b) the software used to access, operate, manage, or configure a device subject to part (a) of this definition, including, but not limited to, the firmware, web or mobile applications, and any related online services, that are advertised, developed, branded, or sold by Defendant, directly or indirectly.
definitions.Customer Information: means the following information from or about an individual customer: (a) user account credentials, such as a login name and password and/or tokens; (b) email address; (c) a site floorplan; (d) name and title of customer contact; (e) Wi-Fi credentials; (f) a financial account number; (g) credit or debit card information; (h) a persistent identifier, such as a customer number held in a "cookie," a static Internet Protocol ("IP") address, a mobile device ID, or a device or component serial number; (i) metadata about product usage (e.g., time, duration of video, IP address, location of camera); and (j) access control elements, including access levels, access groups, and badge numbers.
definitions.Defendant: means Verkada Inc. and its successors and assigns.
definitions.Electronic Mail Address: means a destination, commonly expressed as a string of characters, consisting of a unique user name or mailbox (commonly referred to as the "local part") and a reference to an Internet domain (commonly referred to as the "domain part"), whether or not displayed, to which an Electronic Mail Message can be sent or delivered.
definitions.Electronic Mail Message: means a message sent to a unique Electronic Mail Address.
definitions.Personal Information: means information from or about an individual consumer that Defendant collects through a Covered Product, including: (a) a first and last name; (b) a home or physical address, including street name and name of city or town; (c) an email address or other online contact information, such as an instant messaging user identifier or a screen name; (d) a mobile or other telephone number; (e) date of birth; (f) usernames and passwords; (g) live camera footage; (h) video archives; (i) still images or photos; or (j) audio recordings.

provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from misrepresenting its privacy and security practices, compliance program memberships (including HIPAA and Privacy Shield), HIPAA regulatory status, and the independent status of endorsers or reviewers of its products.
